title: Is urf supposed to be different than standard season 7 games?
body:
League used to be a tactical game of out thinking and out playing your opponent over the course of 30-40 min. When urf was first released in that environment, it was a fun divergence from calculated, tense gameplay decisions. 

Now, Riot has made the game a caricature of itself, adopting the principles of urf for the competitive game mode. You now snowball to victory within the first 5-10 min, have overpowered abilities with nearly no CD, are very rarely gated by any actual costs or drawbacks of using abilities, and every fight is watching people get blown up in half a second. 

Urf isn't a unique game mode anymore, it's become the actual game, which is pretty pathetic if you ask me.

His main problem is not the game lenght. Sure you still need some time to get through to the nexus.

His (and my) main problem is the fact that League once was alot more focused on tactic and actual strategy.
It felt like a game of Quickplay (Chess) alot more than a anything else. You constantly tried to outsmart your opponents. 

But sometime ago they started to call those outsmart champs first boring and created out-play champs and than they've gone even further and threw those old Champs into bad corner of 'ball of stats' 'no counterplay' 'toxic'. 

Does ANYONE really belive those so called BallOfStats Fights were decided from minute 1 by said stats??????????
Obviously not! You won those fights by using brain over reactions! 

Sure you cant react to a targeted stun, but you can plan around it! 

---------------------------------------------------------
Sadly those two types of Champs will never be able to coexists, because you have to draw a line of balance.
At which point an outplay Champ should beat an outsmart Champ?

When played at 100% potencial - than see those Champs never ever been touched! 
At 50% than you will never ever see any tactical Champ above Gold-Plat, because they're incredibly underpowered. 

Sure you could find a point of fake balance if you look for it... but... in the end... every answer below 100% is just unfair... knowing you will always loose if your opponent can play his champs is just wrong. (And its League reality right now)

Can you elaborate for me and what exactly you mean by "ball of stats champs". And in my opinion i feel like outplay champions and out smart champions are the same thing. I hear alot of people say league isnt strategic anymore and i feel like that's not true. It may not have the same strategy that it used to but there definitely is still alot of strategy in the game.

"Ball of Stats champs" are champs who have low amounts of micro-skill expression, e.g. {{champion:36}} {{champion:20}} {{champion:57}} {{champion:54}} {{champion:86}}  . These champs (this is not all of them) don't have many tools that enable outplays in the micro sense. these champs require more macro-outplay, via map movements, wave management, and roams, outsmarting their opponent with said maneuvers

Outplay champs are the exact opposite, as they have high amounts of micro-skill expression, e.g. {{champion:245}} {{champion:157}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:105}} {{champion:81}} . many of this type of champion have dashes or blinks, and (generally) more powerful, skillshot-based abilities. This allows them to dodge other skillshots or skirt the ranges of some abilities, enabling them to outplay their opponents by virtue of the micro-interactions. 

Each character is somewhere between these two labels. In general, the more obvious the gap between a mastery 7 player and a new player, the more outplay-oriented the champion is
